  • jurisdiction: depending on the residence of the account holder, the selection of CFDs that can be traded changes; forex-related CFDs are available everywhere but not, for example, those CFDs that are based on stock indices

Figure 49. Oanda trading application fxTrade Practice

The chapter is organized as follows. Setting Up an Account briefly discusses how to set-up an account. The Oanda API illustrates the necessary steps to access the API. Based on the API access, Retrieving Historical Data retrieves and works with historical data for a certain CFD. Working with Streaming Data introduces to the streaming API of Oanda for data retrieval and visualization. Implementing Trading Strategies in Real-Time implements an automated, algorithmic trading strategy in real-time. Finally, Retrieving Account Information deals with retrieving data about the account itself, like, for example, the current balance or recent trades.

The goal of this chapter is to make use of the approaches and technologies as introduced in previous chapters to automatically trade on the Oanda platform.

8.2. Setting Up an Account

The process for setting up an account with Oanda is simple and efficient. You can chose between a real account and a free demo (practice) account which absolutely suffices to implement what follows (see Oanda account registration (account types) and Oanda account registration (registration form)).

Figure 50. Oanda account registration (account types)
Figure 51. Oanda account registration (registration form)

If the registration is successful and you are logged in to the account on the platform, you should see a starting page as shown in Oanda account starting page. In the upper left corner you find a download link for the fxTrade Practice for Desktop application which you should install. Once it is running, it looks similar to the screen shot shown in Oanda trading application fxTrade Practice.

Figure 52. Oanda account starting page

8.3. The Oanda API

After registration, getting access to the APIs of Oanda is an easy affair. The major ingredients needed are the account number and the access token (API key). You find the account number, for instance, in the area Manage Funds. The access token can be generated in the area Manage API Access (see Oanda API access managing page).[30]

Figure 53. Oanda API access managing page

The following assumes that you have stored the account information in the pyalgo.cfg file (see configparser Module) as follows:

[oanda_v20]
account_id = YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID
access_token = YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

To access the API via Python, the v20 package (Github repository) needs to be installed via

pip install v20

With these prerequisites, you can connect to the API with a few lines of code.

In [1]: import configparser  (1)

In [2]: config = configparser.ConfigParser()  (2)

In [3]: config.read('../pyalgo.cfg')  (3)
Out[4]: ['../pyalgo.cfg']

In [4]: import v20  (4)

In [5]: ctx = v20.Context(
              'api-fxpractice.oanda.com',
              443,
              True,
              application='sample_code',
              token=config['oanda_v20']['access_token'],
              datetime_format='RFC3339')  (5)

In [6]: response = ctx.account.list()  (6)

In [7]: accounts = response.get('accounts')  (6)

In [8]: for account in accounts:
            print('Account: %s' %account)  (6)
Out[8]: Account: id: 101-004-5516121-001
        tags: []
1 Import the configparser module.
2 Instantiates the main ConfigParser object.
3 Read in the configuration data.
4 Imports v20; this package allows to connect to the Oanda API.
5 The main Context object is instantiated for the practice environment (account), using the API access token.
6 To see if it works, these lines of code retrieve the id values for all accounts (there can be multiple sub-accounts in a single main account).

This is a major milestone: being connected to the Oanda API allows now for the retrieval of historical data or the programmatic placing of orders.

8.4. Retrieving Historical Data

A major benefit of working with the Oanda platform is that a complete history of data is accessible via the RESTful API. In this context, complete history refers to the different CFDsnot the underlyings they are defined on.

8.4.1. Looking Up Instruments Available for Trading

For an overview of what instruments can be traded for a given account, the get_instruments function can be used.

In [7]: response = ctx.account.instruments(
                    config['oanda_v20']['account_id']) (1)

In [8]: instruments = response.get('instruments') (1)

In [9]: instruments[0].dict()  (2)

8.4.2. Backtesting a Momentum Strategy on Minute Bars

The example that follows uses the instrument EUR_USD based on the EUR/USD currency pair. The goal is to backtest momentum-based strategies on one-minute bars. The data used is for two days in December 2016. The first step is to retrieve the raw data itself from Oanda.

In [11]: import datetime as dt

In [12]: suffix = '.000000000Z'  (1)

In [13]: fromTime = dt.datetime(2016, 12, 8, 8, 0, 0)  (2)

In [14]: fromTime = fromTime.isoformat('T') + suffix  (3)

In [15]: fromTime  (4)
Out[15]: '2016-12-08T08:00:00.000000000Z'

In [16]: toTime = dt.datetime(2016, 12, 10, 8, 0, 0)  (5)

In [17]: toTime = toTime.isoformat('T') + suffix  (6)

In [18]: res = ctx.instrument.candles(
                             instrument='EUR_USD',  (7)
                             fromTime=fromTime,  (8)
                             toTime=toTime,  (9)
                             granularity='M1',  (10)
                             price='A')  (11)

CPU times: user 58.9 ms, sys: 8.24 ms, total: 67.1 ms
Wall time: 2.03 s

In [19]: res.keys()  (12)
Out[19]: dict_keys(['granularity', 'instrument', 'candles'])
1 This string suffix is needed to conform to the Oanda API requirements regarding start and end times.
2 The fromTime as a datetime object.
3 This adds the required suffix.
4 The resulting time string.
5 The toTime as a datetime object
6 and the suffix added.
7 The instrument for which data is to be retrieved.
8 The fromTime parameter.
9 The toTime parameter.
10 The granularity, here 1 minute bars.
11 The type of data, here ask prices.
12 The raw data is returned as a dict object.

The second step is to transform the raw data into a DataFrame object.

In [20]: import pandas as pd

In [21]: raw = res.get('candles')  (1)

In [22]: raw = [cs.dict() for cs in raw]  (2)

In [23]: for cs in raw:
             cs.update(cs['ask'])
             del cs['ask']  (3)

In [23]: raw[0]  (4)
Out[23]: {'c': '1.07651',
          'complete': True,
          'h': '1.07655',
          'l': '1.07625',
          'o': '1.0765',
          'time': '1481184000.000000000',
          'volume': 68}

In [24]: data = pd.DataFrame(raw)  (5)

In [25]: data['time']= pd.to_datetime(data['time'], unit='s')  (6)

In [25]: data = data.set_index('time')  (7)

In [26]: data.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(data.index)  (8)

In [27]: df.info()  (9)
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
DatetimeIndex: 2208 entries, 2016-12-08 08:00:00 to 2016-12-09 21:59:00
Data columns (total 6 columns):
c           2208 non-null object
complete    2208 non-null bool
h           2208 non-null object
l           2208 non-null object
o           2208 non-null object
volume      2208 non-null int64
dtypes: bool(1), int64(1), object(4)
memory usage: 105.7+ KB

In [28]: data[['c', 'l', 'h', 'o']] = data[
            ['c', 'l', 'h', 'o']].astype('float64')  (10)

In [29]: data = data.rename(columns={'c':'closeAsk', 'l':'lowAsk',
                                     'h':'highAsk', 'o':'openAsk' })  (11)

In [30]: data[['closeAsk', 'volume']].head()  (12)
Out[30]:
                    closeAsk  volume
time
2016-12-08 08:00:00 1.07651   68
2016-12-08 08:01:00 1.07626   37
2016-12-08 08:02:00 1.07638   28
2016-12-08 08:03:00 1.07641   17
2016-12-08 08:04:00 1.07649   16
1 Transforms the raw data first
2 into a list object.
3 Updates all the single dict objects.
4 Shows the resulting first dict object (first one minute bar data set).
5 Creates a new DataFrame object out of the list object.
6 Transforms the entries in the time column to datetime objects.
7 Sets the transformed time column as the index.
8 The index is transformed to a DatetimeIndex object.
9 A total of more than 2,000 data rows is retrieved for two days.
10 The data in the c, l, h, o columns is tranformed to float values and
11 the respective columns are renamed for better readability.

The third step is to implement the vectorized backtesting. The idea is to simultaneously backtest a couple of momentum strategies. The code is straightforward and concise (see also Mastering Vectorized Backtesting). For simplicity, the code uses closeAsk values only.[31]

In [31]: import numpy as np

In [32]: data['returns'] = np.log(data['closeAsk'] /
                                  data['closeAsk'].shift(1))  (1)

In [33]: cols = []  (2)

In [34]: for momentum in [15, 30, 60, 120]:  (3)
             col = 'position_%s' % momentum  (4)
             df[col] = np.sign(data['returns'].rolling(momentum).mean())  (5)
             cols.append(col)  (6)
1 Calculates the log returns based on the closeAsk values.
2 Instantiates an empty list object to collect column names.
3 Defines the time interval in minute bars for the momentum strategy.
4 Defines the name of the column to be used for storage in the DataFrame object.
5 Adds the strategy positionings as a new column.
6 Appends the name of the column to the list object.

The final step is the derivation and plotting of the performances of the different momentum strategies. The plot Performance of different momentum strategies for EUR_USD instrument (minute bars) shows the performances graphically and compares it to the performance of the instrument itself.

In [35]: strats = ['returns']  (1)

In [36]: for col in cols:  (2)
             strat = 'strategy_%s' % col.split('_')[1]  (3)
             data[strat] = data[col].shift(1) * data['returns']  (4)
             strats.append(strat)  (5)

In [37]: data[strats].dropna().cumsum().apply(np.exp).plot()  (6)
1 Defines another list object to store the column names to be plotter later on.
2 Iterates of the columns with the positionings for the different strategies.
3 Derives the name for the new column in which the strategy performance is stored.
4 Calculates the log returns for the different strategies and stores them as new columns.
5 Appends the column names to the list object for later plotting.
6 Plots the cumulative performances for the instrument and the strategies.
Figure 54. Performance of different momentum strategies for EUR_USD instrument (minute bars)

8.4.3. Factoring In Leverage and Margin

In general, when you buy a share of a stock for, say, 100 USD the profit and loss (P&L) calculations are straightforward: the stock price rises by 1 USD, you earn 1 USD (unrealized profit); the stock price falls by 1 USD, you loose 1 USD (unrealized loss). If you buy 10 shares, just multiply the results by 10.

Trading CFDs on the Oanda platform involves leverage and margin. This significantly influences the P&L calculation. For an introduction to and overview of this topic refer to Oanda fxTrade Margin Rules. A simple example can illustrate the major aspects in this context.

Consider an algorithmic trader wants to trade the EUR_USD instrument on the Oanda platform and wants to get a long exposure of 10,000 USD at a ask price of 1.06. Without leverage and margin, the trader (or Python program) would buy 10,000 units of the CFD.[32] If the price of the instrument (exchange rate) rises to 1.065 (as the midpoint rate between bid and ask prices), the absolute profit is 10,000 x 0.005 = 50 or 0.5%.

What impact do leverage and margining then have? Suppose the algorithmic trader chooses a leverage ratio of 20:1 which translates into a 5% margin (= 100% / 20). This in turn implies that the trader only needs to put up a margin upfront of 10,000 USD x 5% = 500 USD (rounded) to get the same exposure. If the price of the instrument then rises to 1.065, the absolute profit stays the same at 50 USD but the relative profit rises to 50 / 500 USD = 10%. The return is considerably amplified by a factor of 20this is the benefit of leverage when things go as desired.

What happens if things go south? Assume the instrument price drops to 1.04 (as the midpoint rate between bid and ask prices) leading to a loss of 10,000 x (1.04 - 1.06) = -200 USD. The relative loss now is -200 / 500 USD = -40% (rounded). If the account the algorithmic trader is trading with has less than 200 USD left in liquidity, the position needs to be closed out since the (regulatory) margin requirements cannot be met anymore. If losses eat up the margin completely, additional funds need to be allocated as margin to keep the trade alive.

Performance of momentum strategies for EUR_USD instrument with 20:1 leverage (minute bars) shows the amplifying effect on the performance of the momentum strategies for a leverage ratio of 20:1. The initial margin of 5% suffices to cover potential losses since it is not eaten up even in the worst case depicted.

In [38]: data[strats].dropna().cumsum().apply(
                    lambda x: x * 20).apply(np.exp).plot()  (1)
1 Multiplies the log returns by a factor of 20 according to the leverage ratio assumed.
Figure 55. Performance of momentum strategies for EUR_USD instrument with 20:1 leverage (minute bars)

8.5. Working with Streaming Data

Working with streaming data is again made simple and straightforward by the Python API wrapper package v20. The package takes care of the socket communication such that the trader only needs to decide what to do with the streaming data. A new Context object is needed via which the data is streamed and that allows it to be printed, for instance.

In [39]: ctx_stream = v20.Context(
                        'stream-fxpractice.oanda.com',  (1)
                        443,
                        True,
                        application='sample_code',
                        token=config['oanda_v20']['access_token'],
                        datetime_format='RFC3339')

In [40]: response = ctx_stream.pricing.stream(  (2)
                        config['oanda_v20']['account_id'],
                        snapshot=True,
                        instruments='EUR_USD')

In [41]: i = 0
         for msg_type, msg in response.parts():
             if msg_type == 'pricing.Price':  (3)
                 i += 1
                 output = '%s (%s) %s/%s' % (msg.instrument,
                      msg.time, msg.bids[0].price,  msg.asks[0].price)  (4)
                 print(output)  (4)
             if i == 10:  (5)
                 break

EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:29:21.609190352Z) 1.06278/1.06289
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:20.886015082Z) 1.06277/1.06289
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:21.383923379Z) 1.06278/1.06289
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:32.443304869Z) 1.06282/1.06292
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:32.511259917Z) 1.06281/1.06293
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:32.730458238Z) 1.06285/1.06296
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:51.145812173Z) 1.0629/1.06301
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:55.116525242Z) 1.06295/1.06307
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:58.026979919Z) 1.06294/1.06305
EUR_USD (2017-03-15T07:30:59.119811116Z) 1.06293/1.06305
1 This Context object accesses the streaming API.
2 Opens the socket connection to the streaming API.
3 From the data stream, the code picks out new pricing data.
4 Prints out elements of the retrieved data sets.
5 If 10 data sets have been retrieved and printed, the loop is finished.

8.6. Implementing Trading Strategies in Real-Time

This section presents a custom class that automatically trades the EUR_USD instrument on the Oanda platform based on a momentum strategy. It is called MomentumTrader and is presented in Oanda custom streaming class that automatically trades a momentum strategy. The following walks through the class line by line, beginning with the __init__ method.

import v20
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import configparser

config = configparser.ConfigParser()
config.read('../pyalgo.cfg')

account_id = config['oanda_v20']['account_id']
access_token = config['oanda_v20']['access_token']


class MomentumTrader(object):
    def __init__(self, momentum, instrument, units, *args, **kwargs):

        self.ticks = 0  (1)
        self.position = 0  (2)
        self.data = pd.DataFrame()  (3)
        self.momentum = momentum  (4)
        self.account_id = account_id  (5)
        self.instrument = instrument  (6)
        self.units = units  (7)
        self.ctx = v20.Context(  (8)
            'api-fxpractice.oanda.com',
            443,
            True,
            application='sample_code',
            token=access_token,
            datetime_format='RFC3339'
        )
        self.ctx_stream = v20.Context(  (9)
            'stream-fxpractice.oanda.com',
            443,
            True,
            application='sample_code',
            token=access_token,
            datetime_format='RFC3339'
        )
1 Counter for the number of ticks retrieved.
2 Initial position value (i.e. market neutral).
3 The DataFrame object to collect the tick data.
4 The account_id of the (sub-)account to be used.
5 The instrument to be traded.
6 The numbers of units to be traded.
7 The standard Context object.
8 The streaming Context object.

A necessary prerequisite to automatically trade an instrument on Oanda is the ability to programmatically place buy and sell orders. To this end, the class defines the create_order method.

    def create_order(self, units):
        ''' Places orders with Oanda. '''
        request = self.ctx.order.market(
            self.account_id,  (1)
            instrument=self.instrument,  (2)
            units=units,  (3)
        )
        order = request.get('orderFillTransaction')  (4)
        print('\n\n', order.dict(), '\n')  (5)
1 The (sub-)account for which the order shall be placed.
2 The instruments for which the order is.
3 The number of units to be ordered (positive=buy order or negative=sell order).
4 Places the order.
5 Prints the order information.

The start method starts the streaming of the data and triggers actions to be taken when new data arrives.

    def start(self):
        ''' Starts the streaming of data and the triggering of actions. '''
        response = self.ctx_stream.pricing.stream(
            self.account_id,
            snapshot=True,
            instruments=self.instrument
        )  (1)
        for msg_type, msg in response.parts():
            if msg_type == 'pricing.Price':
                self.on_success(msg.time, msg.asks[0].price)  (2)
            if self.ticks == 250:  (3)
                if self.position == 1:
                    self.create_order(-self.units)  (4)
                elif self.position == -1:
                    self.create_order(self.units)  (5)
                return 'Finished.'
1 Opens the socket communication to stream the real-time data.
2 Whenever there is new pricing information, the on_success method is called, providing time and price data.
3 If a certain (arbitrary) number of ticks is retrieved
4 the long position is closed out (via sell order).
5 the short position is closed out (via buy order).

The major method is the on_success method which implements the trading logic for the momentum strategy.

    def on_success(self, time, ask):
        ''' Takes actions when new tick data arrives. '''
        self.ticks += 1  (1)
        print(self.ticks, end=' ')  (1)
        self.data = self.data.append(
            pd.DataFrame({'time': [time], 'ask': [ask]}))  (2)
        self.data.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(self.data['time'])  (3)
        resam = self.data.resample('1min').last()  (4)
        # resam = resam.ffill()  (5)
        resam['returns'] = np.log(resam['ask'] / resam['ask'].shift(1))  (6)
        resam['position'] = np.sign(
            resam['returns'].rolling(self.momentum).mean())  (7)
        # print(resam[['ask', 'returns', 'position']].tail())  (8)

        if resam['position'].ix[-1] == 1:  (9)
            if self.position == 0:  (10)
                self.create_order(self.units)  (11)
            elif self.position == -1:  (12)
                self.create_order(self.units * 2)  (13)
            self.position = 1  (14)
        elif resam['position'].ix[-1] == -1:  (15)
            if self.position == 0:  (16)
                self.create_order(-self.units)  (17)
            elif self.position == 1:  (18)
                self.create_order(-self.units * 2)  (19)
            self.position = -1  (20)
1 Increases the number of ticks by 1 and prints it.
2 The new raw data is appended to self.data.
3 The index is transformed to a DatetimeIndex object.
4 The raw (tick) data is resampled to a time interval of five seconds, taking the last available value as the relevant one.
5 In case, empty intervals are filled to have a complete data set (if desired).
6 This calculates the log returns given the resampled data.
7 The positioning is derived according to the momentum strategy (via an online algorithm).
8 Prints out the last couple of rows (if desired).
9 Checks whether the latest positioning (signal) is 1 (long).
10 If the current market position is 0 (neutral)
11 a buy order for self.units is initiated.
12 If it is -1 (short)
13 a buy order for 2 * self.units is initiated.
14 The market position self.position is set to 1 (long).
15 Checks whether the latest positioning (signal) is -1 (short).
16 If the current market position is 0 (neutral)
17 a sell order for -self.units is initiated.
18 If it is 1 (long)
19 a sell order for -2 * self.units is initiated.
20 The market position self.position is set to -1 (short).

Based on this class, getting started with automated, algorithmic trading is just three lines of code. The code below initiates an automated trading session.

In [1]: import MomentTrader_v20 as MT

In [2]: mt = MT.MomentumTrader(momentum=6,  (1)
                               instrument='EUR_USD',  (2)
                               units=50000)  (3)

In [3]: mt.start()
1 The momentum parameter is defined which is applied to the resampled data intervals.
2 The instrument parameters is specified.
3 The units parameter is set.

Below is an example output showing the number of ticks received and also the trades executed.

8.7. Retrieving Account Information

With regard to account information, transaction history, etc. the Oanda RESTful API is also quite powerful and flexible. For example, after the execution of the momentum strategy in the previous section, the algorithmic trader might want to inspect the current balance of the trading account. This is possible via the account.summary method.

In [4]: response = ctx.account.summary(account_id)  (1)

In [5]: acc_summary = response.get('account')  (1)

In [6]: acc_summary.dict()  (2)
Out[6]:

Information about the last few trades is received as follows:

In [10]: response = ctx.transaction.since(account_id, id=497)  (1)

In [11]: transactions = response.get('transactions')  (2)

In [12]: for transaction in transactions:
            print('\n', transaction.dict())  (3)
1 Fixes the starting id value from which on to retrieve the dates (needs to be adjusted to account for the current value of id).
2 Fetches the transactions data.
3 Prints out the single transactions.

Of course, this information might be processed and reformatted for better reading.

In [13]: for trans in transactions:
             trans = trans.dict()
             templ = '%s | %14s | %12s'
             print(templ % (trans['time'],
                            trans['instrument'],
                            trans['units']))
2017-03-15T08:54:22.744421504Z |        EUR_USD |     100000.0
2017-03-15T08:54:22.744421504Z |        EUR_USD |     100000.0
2017-03-15T08:54:25.247064166Z |        EUR_USD |      50000.0
2017-03-15T08:54:25.247064166Z |        EUR_USD |      50000.0
2017-03-15T09:04:30.849342658Z |        EUR_USD |     -50000.0
2017-03-15T09:04:30.849342658Z |        EUR_USD |     -50000.0
2017-03-15T09:04:34.112940747Z |        EUR_USD |     -50000.0
2017-03-15T09:04:34.112940747Z |        EUR_USD |     -50000.0

8.8. Conclusions

The Oanda platform allows an easy and straightforward entry into the world of automated, algorithmic trading. Oanda specializes in so-called Contracts for Difference (CFDs). Depending on the country of residence of the trader there is a great variety of instruments that can be traded.

A major advantage of Oanda from a technological point of view are the modern, powerful APIs that can be easily accessed via a dedicated Python wrapper package (v20). This chapter shows how to set up an account, to connect to the APIs with Python, to retrieve historical data (one minute bars) for backtesting purposes, to retrieve streaming data in real-time, to automatically trade a CFD based on a momentum strategy and to retrieve account information as well as the detailed transaction history.

8.9. Further Resources

Visit the help and support pages of Oanda under https://oanda.secure.force.com/HelpAndSupport to learn more about the platform and important aspects of CFD trading.

The developer portal of Oanda http://developer.oanda.com/rest-live/introduction/ provides a detailed description of the APIs.

8.10. Python Scripts

Example 21. Oanda custom streaming class that automatically trades a momentum strategy
#
# Python Script
# with Momentum Trading Class
# for Oanda v20
#
# Python for Algorithmic Trading
# (c) Dr. Yves J. Hilpisch
# The Python Quants GmbH
#
import v20
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import configparser

config = configparser.ConfigParser()
config.read('../pyalgo.cfg')

account_id = config['oanda_v20']['account_id']
access_token = config['oanda_v20']['access_token']


class MomentumTrader(object):
    def __init__(self, momentum, instrument, units, *args, **kwargs):

        self.ticks = 0
        self.position = 0
        self.data = pd.DataFrame()
        self.momentum = momentum
        self.account_id = account_id
        self.instrument = instrument
        self.units = units
        self.ctx = v20.Context(
            'api-fxpractice.oanda.com',
            443,
            True,
            application='sample_code',
            token=access_token,
            datetime_format='RFC3339'
        )
        self.ctx_stream = v20.Context(
            'stream-fxpractice.oanda.com',
            443,
            True,
            application='sample_code',
            token=access_token,
            datetime_format='RFC3339'
        )

    def create_order(self, units):
        ''' Places orders with Oanda. '''
        request = self.ctx.order.market(
            self.account_id,
            instrument=self.instrument,
            units=units,
        )
        order = request.get('orderFillTransaction')
        print('\n\n', order.dict(), '\n')

    def start(self):
        ''' Starts the streaming of data and the triggering of actions. '''
        response = self.ctx_stream.pricing.stream(
            self.account_id,
            snapshot=True,
            instruments=self.instrument
        )
        for msg_type, msg in response.parts():
            if msg_type == 'pricing.Price':
                self.on_success(msg.time, msg.asks[0].price)
            if self.ticks == 250:
                if self.position == 1:
                    self.create_order(-self.units)
                elif self.position == -1:
                    self.create_order(self.units)
                return 'Finished.'

    def on_success(self, time, ask):
        ''' Takes actions when new tick data arrives. '''
        self.ticks += 1
        print(self.ticks, end=' ')
        self.data = self.data.append(
            pd.DataFrame({'time': [time], 'ask': [ask]}))
        self.data.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(self.data['time'])
        resam = self.data.resample('1min').last()
        # resam = resam.ffill()
        resam['returns'] = np.log(resam['ask'] / resam['ask'].shift(1))
        resam['position'] = np.sign(
            resam['returns'].rolling(self.momentum).mean())
        # print(resam[['ask', 'returns', 'position']].tail())

        if resam['position'].ix[-1] == 1:
            if self.position == 0:
                self.create_order(self.units)
            elif self.position == -1:
                self.create_order(self.units * 2)
            self.position = 1
        elif resam['position'].ix[-1] == -1:
            if self.position == 0:
                self.create_order(-self.units)
            elif self.position == 1:
                self.create_order(-self.units * 2)
            self.position = -1

9. Stock Trading with Interactive Brokers

Financial institutions like to call what they do trading. Lets be honest. Its not trading; its betting.

Graydon Carter

9.1. Introduction

Interactive Brokers (IB) is one of the leading online brokers, if not the leading broker, for retail investors and traders. IB provides access to more than 100 trading venues in 24 countries offering trading capabilities for a great variety of financial instruments. Along the lines of the criteria for broker selection outlined in CFD Trading with Oanda, below an overview of what characterizes IB as an online broker.

  • instruments: IB allows trading and direct market access to stocks, options, futures, forex, bonds, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and Contracts for Difference (CFDs) from a single account

  • strategies: in addition to buying financial instruments, IB also allows the short selling of certain instruments according to specified rules

  • costs: IB claims to be one of the cheapest online brokers; according to a ranking by Barrons magazine, IB also is the cheapest from a list of 16 online brokers with monthly fees of 847 USD compared to an average of 1,905 USD (for a stylized trader with a certain trading volume and frequency)

  • technology: the major tool provided by IB for trading is the Trader Workstation (TWS)see Interactive Brokers Trader Workstation (TWS) (source: IB web site)which is a desktop application that also runs a local proxy providing API access to historical financial data, portfolio and order data as well as real-time, streaming data

  • jurisdiction: IB is active around the globe providing a full set of instruments and trading capabilities in many countries; check on the IB countries page from where you get access to which trading locations

Figure 56. Interactive Brokers Trader Workstation (TWS)

9.2. Setting up an Account

Setting up a trial account with IB is simple and straightforward. You just need to fill out a short form with some basic data as shown in Setting up a trial account with Interactive Brokers (in German language).

Figure 57. Setting up a trial account with Interactive Brokers

Once logged in, you can then download the TWS application for you operating system. Starting the application then requires the previously chosen user name and password. TWS then might show up as in Trader Workstation after login with trial credentials on your desktop.

Figure 58. Trader Workstation after login with trial credentials

The arrangement of the different panels of TWS might be changed or new windows might pop up depending on what you request from the application. TWS break out window with option chain data shows a break out window with option chain data for a stock index.

Figure 59. TWS break out window with option chain data

Contrary to the Oanda paper trading account as used in CFD Trading with Oanda, TWS does not offer full access to all capabilities or historical/streaming data sets. However, the basic approach of TWS and the API realized by the local proxy can be explored seamlessly.

9.3. Python and the IB API

Python is an officially supported language to access the IB API (alongside to C++ and Java). However, this is rather new and the Python support is pretty native and not very conveniet. On the other hand, there are a feweven if not really regularly maintainedPython packages available as open source that allow access to the IB API. The Python package used in the following is called IbPy and has nothing to do with the recently published native Python support by Interactive Brokers. Recently, there has been some maintenance work and the package seems to be used quite a bit by the Python and trading communities. You can install the package via

pip install IbPy2

Alternatively, it can be installed from Github directly via

git clone https://github.com/blampe/IbPy.git
cd IbPy
python setup.py install

No matter what technology is used to access the IB API, some default settings of TWS need to be changed (under File-Global Configuration-API). Changing TWS settings for API access (I) shows the API-Settings screen with three important configurations:

  • Enable ActiveX and Socket Clients must be enabled

  • Read-Only API must be disabled

  • Allow connection from local host only must be disabled

Figure 60. Changing TWS settings for API access (I)

In addition, under API-Precautions the option Bypass order precautions for API orders should be enabled as shown in Changing TWS settings for API access (II)

Figure 61. Changing TWS settings for API access (II)

9.4. A Wrapper Class for the IB API

Although IbPy allows Python-based access to the IB API, it is not really convenient. The Python Quants therefore have developed a Python wrapper class called tpqibsee Python wrapper class for IB API based on IbPywhich simplifies the IB API access considerably and provides a modern interface to do so.

Unfortunately, some functions cannot be tested even if there is a trial account. Therefore, the overview of tpqib is based on the demo account with

user: edemo
password: demouser

Using this account allows the illustration of all functions. However, the data is sample data onlywhich should suffice for a technical demo.

The first step is to instantiate a connection object.

In [1]: import tpqib  (1)

In [2]: con = tpqib.tpqibcon()  (2)
Server Version: 76
TWS Time at connection:20170102 09:49:23 CET
1 Imports the tpqib module with the wrapper class.
2 Instantiates a connection object based on the class.

When a connection is set up, you need to confirm access for the incoming connection with TWS as shown in Confirming incoming API connection with TWS.

Figure 62. Confirming incoming API connection with TWS

9.5. Retrieving Historical Data from IB

A central object when working with the IB API is the contract. For example, if you want to retrieve historical data for the Apple, Inc. stock, you need to define a respective contract object for this instrument.

In [3]: aapl_contract = con.create_contract('AAPL', 'STK', 'SMART',
                                            'SMART', 'USD')  (1)

In [4]: con.req_contract_details(aapl_contract)  (2)
Symbol: AAPL, Type: STK, Exchange: SMART, Primary Exchange: NASDAQ,Currency: USD

In [5]: con.get_market_data_once(aapl_contract)  (3)
Last timestamp: 2017-01-02 10:17:00, Ask price: 116.3, Ask size: 2,Bid price:
116.29, Bid size: 2, Low: 112.66, High: 119.82, Close: 116.26, Volume: 22385,
Last price: 116.29,Last size: 3, Halted: 0.0
1 Creates the contract object for AAPL; the syntax is create_contract(symbol, security type, primary exchange, exchange, currency).
2 Retrieves the contract details from the IB API.
3 Retrieves the most current market data for the contract; the execution is asynchronous which means that the data retrieval and presentation might be delayed even if the method call seems to be finished.

The above code retrieves a single tick data set. Of course, larger historical data sets can be pulled as well.

In [6]: import datetime as dt  (1)

In [7]: end_date = dt.datetime.now()  (2)

In [8]: request_id = con.request_historical_data(aapl_contract, end_date,
                                          '1 W', '8 hours', 'TRADES')  (3)

In [9]: request_id  (4)
Out[9]: 2

In [10]: con.get_historical_data(request_id)  (5)
Out[10]:

                    WAP     close   count hasGaps high    low     open    volume
date
2017-03-12 06:00:00 138.953 138.73  13235 False   145.80  132.83  138.88  155
2017-03-12 09:00:00 139.127 138.73  34894 False   149.47  132.00  138.69  411
2017-03-12 17:00:00 138.669 138.71  35150 False   150.00  131.94  138.74  412
2017-03-13 01:00:00 138.474 138.72  17551 False   147.25  131.32  138.70  205
2017-03-13 05:00:00 138.702 138.52  17454 False   149.24  132.55  138.80  205
2017-03-13 09:00:00 138.272 138.01  34991 False   149.44  131.35  138.52  410
2017-03-13 17:00:00 138.312 138.22  34931 False   149.72  131.55  138.01  410
2017-03-14 01:00:00 138.255 138.12  17482 False   150.25  131.50  138.22  204
2017-03-14 05:00:00 138.068 138.08  17371 False   144.73  131.33  138.10  204
2017-03-14 09:00:00 138.332 138.75  34738 False   148.84  131.20  138.08  407
2017-03-14 17:00:00 138.884 139.19  35055 False   147.66  131.91  138.75  411
2017-03-15 01:00:00 139.087 138.99  17512 False   148.33  132.97  139.19  205
2017-03-15 05:00:00 138.988 138.74  17564 False   146.59  132.27  138.95  205
2017-03-15 09:00:00 138.732 138.88  11294 False   147.63  131.97  138.76  132
1 Imports the datetime module as dt.
2 Fixes the end date for data retrieval.
3 Requests historical data for the current week in eight hour intervals; the syntax is request_historical_data(contract, end_date_time, duration, bar_size, what_to_show, use_RTH, format_date).
4 The request_id number
5 based on which the data then gets retrieved; the return object is a pandas DataFrame object.

Note that in the demo version of TWS, data retrieval is strongly limited and also really slow. It is indeed only sufficient for a technical demo but not really more. You also need to remember that most of the methods work asynchronously and that it might seem for quite a while that a method call was not successful since it does not return anything immediately.

Of course, different granularities are also possible. High, Close, Low stock price data from IB API graphically shows a sub-set of the data retrieved.

In [11]: request_id = con.request_historical_data(aapl_contract, end_date,
                                          '1 W', '1 min', 'TRADES')  (1)

In [12]: request_id  (2)
Out[12]: 3

In [13]: data = con.get_historical_data(request_id)  (3)

In [14]: data.info()  (4)
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>

4 Shows the meta information of the DataFrame object.

There are a number of valid bar sizes to retrieve historical data for via the IB API.

          '5 secs',

          '15 secs',
