9.6. Working with Streaming Data from the IB API

Automated, algorithmic trading requires the retrieval of real-time data. To this end, The IB API allows the streaming of financial data. In this context, working with streaming data is made simple again by the use of tpqib. There are multiple types of streaming data that can be retrieved as shown below.

In [17]: tpqib.STREAMING_DATA_TYPES
Out[17]: ['lastTimestamp',
          'askPrice',
          'askSize',
          'bidPrice',
          'bidSize',
          'low',
          'high',
          'close',
          'volume',
          'lastPrice',
          'lastSize',
          'halted']

When using the the request_market_data method, a callback function needs to be provided that defines what to do with the retrieved streaming data.

In [18]: def print_bid_ask_price(field, value):  (1)
            if field == 'bidPrice':  (2)
                print(dt.datetime.now(), '| bid is %s' % value)  (3)
            if field == 'askPrice':  (4)
                print(dt.datetime.now(), '| ask is %s' % value)  (5)

In [19]: request_id = con.request_market_data(aapl_contract,  (6)
                                              print_bid_ask_price)  (7)

2017-03-15 11:40:10.262515 | bid is 135.16
2017-03-15 11:40:10.262916 | ask is 135.18
2017-03-15 11:40:22.789972 | ask is 135.17
2017-03-15 11:40:39.249456 | bid is 135.14
2017-03-15 11:40:39.249938 | ask is 135.16
2017-03-15 11:40:59.556250 | bid is 135.16
2017-03-15 11:40:59.556624 | ask is 135.17
2017-03-15 11:41:20.631641 | bid is 135.14
2017-03-15 11:41:20.632007 | ask is 135.16
2017-03-15 11:41:31.608219 | bid is 135.16
2017-03-15 11:41:31.608597 | ask is 135.17
2017-03-15 11:41:48.895520 | bid is 135.14
2017-03-15 11:41:48.895893 | ask is 135.16

In [20]: con.cancel_market_data(request_id)  (8)
1 Defines the callback function.
2 Picks out the bidPrice data point
3 and prints it with a timestamp.
4 Picks out the askPrice data point
5 and prints it with a timestamp.
6 Data is requested for the AAPL contract object
7 and processed according to the print_bid_ask_price function; the streaming happens asynchronously.
8 Given the request_id number, the asynchronous streaming is stopped.

Due to the (partly random) nature of the sample data retrieved, no backtesting example is provided here. However, from a pure Python programming point of view the data can be processed as done multiple times before.

9.7. Implementing Trading Strategies in Real-Time

This section implements a simple moving average (SMA) long only trading strategy for the Apple, Inc. stock with Interactive Brokers. The previous section introduces to the processing of streaming data from the IB API. What is missing so far is the ability to place orders. The wrapper class from tpqib takes care of this as well. The code below shows a complete example that sets everything up, places a buy order and then a sell order.

In [1]: import tpqib

In [2]: import numpy as np

In [3]: import pandas as pd

In [4]: import datetime as dt

In [5]: con = tpqib.tpqibcon()
Server Version: 76
TWS Time at connection:20170103 11:20:19 CET

In [6]: symbol = 'AAPL'

In [7]: shares = 100

In [8]: contract = con.create_contract(symbol, 'STK', 'SMART', 'SMART', 'USD')

In [9]: buy_order = con.create_order('MKT', shares, 'Buy')  (1)

In [10]: sell_order = con.create_order('MKT', shares, 'Sell')  (2)

In [11]: con.place_order(contract, buy_order)  (3)
Order: BUY 100 AAPL
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled

In [12]: con.place_order(contract, sell_order)  (4)
Order: SELL 100 AAPL
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
1 Defines a buy order object for a certain number of shares.
2 Defines a sell order object for a certain number of shares.
3 Places the buy order given the order definition and the contract specification.
4 Places the sell order given the order definition and the contract specification.

The status of the order is not only printed, there is also an audio message when the order is filled as well as a small pop-up window as shown in Confirmation for an order being filled.

Figure 64. Confirmation for an order being filled

The placing of orders can now be combined with the streaming functionality to implement an automated trading strategy based on SMAs (for five 1 second intervals and ten 1 second intervals). First the function defining the trading strategy.

def SMA_strategy(field, value):
    global data  (1)
    global ticks  (1)
    global resam  (1)
    global position  (1)
    global request_id  (1)
    if field == 'bidPrice':  (2)
        ticks += 1
        timestamp = dt.datetime.now()
        data = data.append(pd.DataFrame({'bid': value},
                                        index=[timestamp]))
        print('%3d | ' % ticks, timestamp, '| bid is %s' % value)
    elif field == 'askPrice':  (3)
        ticks += 1
        timestamp = dt.datetime.now()
        data = data.append(pd.DataFrame({'ask': value},
                                        index=[timestamp]))
        print('%3d | ' % ticks, timestamp, '| ask is %s' % value)
    resam = data.resample('1s').last().ffill()  (4)
    if len(resam) >= 10:  (5)
        resam['SMA1'] = resam.mean(axis=1).rolling(5).mean()  (6)
        resam['SMA2'] = resam.mean(axis=1).rolling(10).mean()  (6)
        resam['position'] = np.where(resam['SMA1'] > resam['SMA2'], 1, -1)  (7)
        if resam['position'].ix[-1] == 1 and position == 0:  (8)
            con.place_order(contract, buy_order)  (9)
            position = 1  (10)
        elif resam['position'].ix[-1] == -1 and position == 1:  (11)
            con.place_order(contract, sell_order)  (12)
            position = 0  (13)
1 Declares a couple of variables to be global.
2 Appends a bidPrice data point to the DataFrame object.
3 Appends an askPrice data point to the DataFrame object.
4 Resamples the DataFrame object to a 1 second interval.
5 Checks whether there are enough data rows in the resampled DataFrame object.
6 Calculates the SMAs and stores them in two new columns.
7 Derives the positioning according to the SMA values.
8 Checks whether there is a buy signal while the position is neutral.
9 Places a buy order.
10 Sets the position to 1 (long).
11 Checks whether there is a sell signal while the position is long.
12 Places a sell order.
13 Sets the position to 0 (neutral).

With the SMAStrategy function available, automated trading of Apple, Inc. shares is straightforward.

In [13]: ticks = 0  (1)

In [14]: position = 0  (2)

In [16]: data = pd.DataFrame()  (3)

In [17]: request_id = con.request_market_data(contract, SMA_strategy)  (4)
  1 |  2017-03-15 11:44:38.512996 | bid is 135.12
  2 |  2017-03-15 11:44:38.518209 | ask is 135.14
  3 |  2017-03-15 11:44:47.114682 | bid is 135.13
  4 |  2017-03-15 11:44:47.127876 | ask is 135.15
Order: BUY 100 AAPL
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
  5 |  2017-03-15 11:44:51.333085 | bid is 135.14
  6 |  2017-03-15 11:44:51.343326 | ask is 135.16
  7 |  2017-03-15 11:44:59.342581 | bid is 135.16
  8 |  2017-03-15 11:44:59.353576 | ask is 135.17
  9 |  2017-03-15 11:45:07.855217 | bid is 135.14
 10 |  2017-03-15 11:45:07.866124 | ask is 135.16
 11 |  2017-03-15 11:45:58.966638 | bid is 135.16
 12 |  2017-03-15 11:45:58.977207 | ask is 135.17
 13 |  2017-03-15 11:46:26.211742 | ask is 135.18
 14 |  2017-03-15 11:46:32.543550 | bid is 135.17
 15 |  2017-03-15 11:46:32.554671 | ask is 135.19
 16 |  2017-03-15 11:46:43.224134 | bid is 135.19
 17 |  2017-03-15 11:46:43.235763 | ask is 135.21
 18 |  2017-03-15 11:46:52.940754 | bid is 135.23
 19 |  2017-03-15 11:46:52.949703 | ask is 135.25
 20 |  2017-03-15 11:47:17.408378 | bid is 135.25
 21 |  2017-03-15 11:47:17.416878 | ask is 135.26
 22 |  2017-03-15 11:47:34.905485 | bid is 135.27
 23 |  2017-03-15 11:47:34.914984 | ask is 135.29
 24 |  2017-03-15 11:47:49.306095 | bid is 135.25
 25 |  2017-03-15 11:47:49.317150 | ask is 135.26
 26 |  2017-03-15 11:47:49.554387 | ask is 135.25
Order: SELL 100 AAPL
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
    Filled: 100, Status: Filled
 27 |  2017-03-15 11:47:49.657958 | ask is 135.26
 28 |  2017-03-15 11:47:56.330200 | bid is 135.23
 29 |  2017-03-15 11:47:56.339885 | ask is 135.25

In [18]: con.cancel_market_data(request_id)  (5)
1 Sets the number of ticks retrieved to 0.
2 Sets the market position to 0 (neutral).
3 Instantiates an empty DataFrame object to collect the tick data.
4 Starts the automated trading based on the contract object and the SMAStrategy function definition.
5 Stops the automated trading (manually).

Since the respective DataFrame objects are declared to be global variables, their content can be accessed even after the execution of the trading strategy has been stopped.

In [19]: data.tail()  (1)
Out[19]:
                            ask     bid
2017-03-15 11:47:49.317150  135.26  NaN
2017-03-15 11:47:49.554387  135.25  NaN
2017-03-15 11:47:49.657958  135.26  NaN
2017-03-15 11:47:56.330200  NaN 135.23
2017-03-15 11:47:56.339885  135.25  NaN

In [20]: resam.tail()  (2)
                    ask     bid     SMA1    SMA2        position
2017-03-15 11:47:52 135.26  135.25  135.260 135.271667  -1
2017-03-15 11:47:53 135.26  135.25  135.255 135.269167  -1
2017-03-15 11:47:54 135.26  135.25  135.255 135.266667  -1
2017-03-15 11:47:55 135.26  135.25  135.255 135.264167  -1
2017-03-15 11:47:56 135.25  135.23  135.252 135.260567  -1
1 The raw tick data as collected.
2 The resampled data with the SMAs and positionings.

9.8. Retrieving Account Information

It is helpful to be able to programmatically retrieve account information from the IB API. In order to have some stock positions, the code below places buy orders for different symbols first.

In [1]: import tpqib

In [2]: con = tpqib.tpqibcon()
Server Version: 76
TWS Time at connection:20170103 11:43:05 CET

In [3]: symbols = ['AAPL', 'GOOG', 'YHOO']  (1)

In [4]: contracts = {sym: con.create_contract(sym, 'STK', 'SMART', 'SMART', 'USD')
                     for sym in symbols}  (2)

In [5]: contracts  (3)
Out[5]: {'AAPL': <ib.ext.Contract.Contract at 0x113b64a20>,
         'GOOG': <ib.ext.Contract.Contract at 0x113b64a58>,
         'YHOO': <ib.ext.Contract.Contract at 0x113b64b70>}

In [6]: buy_order = con.create_order('MKT', 50, 'Buy')  (4)

In [7]: for sym in symbols:
            con.place_order(contracts[sym], buy_order)  (5)
Order: BUY 50 AAPL
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
Order: BUY 50 GOOG
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
Order: BUY 50 YHOO
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled

In [8]: con.req_positions()  (6)
Quantity: 50, Symbol: YHOO, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 46.23
Quantity: 50, Symbol: AAPL, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 135.28
Quantity: 50, Symbol: GOOG, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 839.24
1 Defines the symbols for which to place orders.
2 Creates a dict object with the contracts for the symbols
3 and prints the object data.
4 Creates a buy order object for 50 shares.
5 Places buy orders for all symbols.
6 Shows the portfolio positions given the orders.

In the same fashion, sell orders can be placed to clean up the portfolio.

In [9]: sell_order = con.create_order('MKT', 50, 'Sell')  (1)

In [10]: for sym in symbols:
             con.place_order(contracts[sym], sell_order)  (2)
Order: SELL 50 AAPL
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
Quantity: 0, Symbol: AAPL, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
Order: SELL 50 GOOG
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
Order: SELL 50 YHOO
    Filled: 0, Status: Submitted
Quantity: 0, Symbol: YHOO, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
Quantity: 0, Symbol: GOOG, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled
    Filled: 50, Status: Filled

In [13]: con.req_positions()  (3)
Quantity: 0, Symbol: YHOO, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
Quantity: 0, Symbol: AAPL, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
Quantity: 0, Symbol: GOOG, Currency: USD, Average Cost: 0.0
1 A sell order object is created.
2 The sell orders are placed; note that all orders are executed asynchronously to that some printed lines might appear in not-expected places.
3 The new portfolio positions are retrieved and shown.

9.9. Conclusions

This chapter is about stock trading with Interactive Brokers, one of the leading online brokers for retail investors and traders. Python is not officially supported by Interactive Brokers. However, there are a few Python packages available as open source from which this chapter uses IbPy.

To make life for the algorithmic trader a bit more convenient, the IbPy package is not used directly but rather wrapped into a Python class contained in the tpqib module (see Python wrapper class for IB API based on IbPy). This simplifies the most common tasks when working with the IB API considerably and offers a modern user interface to do so.

In any case, this chapter shows an efficient and convenient approach to get started with algorithmic trading on the Interactive Brokers platform by using Python.

9.10. Further Resources

Unfortunately, there are not too many resources available that show how to use Python in combination with the Interactive Brokers API. Most resources are in the form of videos (webinars, tutorials, etc.) available on YouTube. A search there might be a good starting point.

A major problem is that Interactive Brokers just recently started to officially support Python as a programming language to interact with the API. The hope remains that there will be more convenient `official` approaches available in the near future.

On the Github page of the IbPy package, you find a concise Getting Started page.

9.11. Python Scripts

Example 22. Python wrapper class for IB API based on IbPy
#
# Python Wrapper Class for
# Interactive Brokers API
# based on IbPy
#
# Python for Algorithmic Trading
# (c) Dr. Yves J. Hilpisch
# The Python Quants GmbH
#
from ib.ext.Contract import Contract
from ib.ext.Order import Order
from ib.ext.TickType import TickType as TickType
from ib.opt.dispatcher import Dispatcher
from ib.opt.receiver import Receiver
from ib.opt.sender import Sender

import ib.opt
from time import sleep
import datetime as dt
import pandas as pd

EXCLUDE = ['contractDetails', 'contractDetailsEnd', 'position', 'positionEnd',
           'error', 'accountSummary', 'openOrder', 'orderStatus',
           'execDetails', 'commissionReport', 'connectionClosed',
           'nextValidId', 'tickGeneric', 'tickString', 'tickSnapshotEnd',
           'tickPrice', 'tickSize', 'historicalData']

VALID_BAR_SIZES = ['1 sec', '5 secs', '10 secs', '15 secs', '30 secs',
                   '1 min', '2 mins', '3 mins', '5 mins', '10 mins',
                   '15 mins', '20 mins', '30 mins', '1 hour', '2 hours',
                   '3 hours', '4 hours', '8 hours', '1 day', '1 week',
                   '1 month']

WHAT_TO_SHOW = ['TRADES', 'MIDPOINT', 'ASK', 'BID', 'BID_ASK',
                'HISTORICAL_VOLATILITY', 'OPTION_IMPLIED_VOLATILITY',
                'REBATE_RATE', 'FREE_RATE']

STREAMING_DATA_TYPES = ['lastTimestamp', 'askPrice', 'askSize',
                        'bidPrice', 'bidSize', 'low', 'high', 'close',
                        'volume', 'lastPrice', 'lastSize', 'halted']


class tpqibcon(ib.opt.Connection):
    def __init__(self, host='127.0.0.1', port=7497, clientId=0,
                 receiver=None, sender=None, dispatcher=None):
        dispatcher = Dispatcher() if dispatcher is None else dispatcher
        receiver = Receiver(dispatcher) if receiver is None else receiver
        sender = Sender(dispatcher) if sender is None else sender
        super(tpqibcon, self).__init__(
            host, port, clientId, receiver, sender, dispatcher)
        self.reported_orders = set()
        self.next_order_id = None
        self.next_data_request_id = 1
        self.ticker_data = dict()
        self.tick_callbacks = dict()
        self.print_once = set()
        self.hist_data_loading = dict()
        self.hist_data = dict()
        try:
            self.connect()
        except:
            raise IOError("Can not connect %s on port %s" % (host, port))
        sleep(1)
        self.register_handlers()
        self.reqIds(-1)

    def register_handlers(self):
        self.register(self.on_next_order_id, 'NextValidId')
        self.register(self.on_contract_details, 'ContractDetails')
        self.register(self.on_position_request, 'Position')
        self.register(self.on_account_summary, 'AccountSummary')
        self.register(self.on_open_order, 'OpenOrder')
        self.register(self.on_order_status, 'OrderStatus')
        self.register(self.on_commission_report, 'CommissionReport')
        self.register(self.on_connection_closed, 'ConnectionClosed')
        self.register(self.on_tick, 'TickSize')
        self.register(self.on_tick, 'TickPrice')
        self.register(self.on_tick, 'TickGeneric')
        self.register(self.on_tick, 'TickString')
        self.register(self.on_snapshot_end, 'TickSnapshotEnd')
        self.register(self.on_hist_data, 'HistoricalData')
        self.register(self.error_handler, 'Error')
        self.registerAll(self.reply_handler)

    def create_contract(self, symbol, sec_type, exch, prim_exch, curr):
        ''' Create a contract object defining what will
        be purchased, at which exchange and in which currency.

        symbol - the ticker symbol for the contract
        sec_type - the security type for the contract ('STK' is 'stock')
        exch - the exchange to carry out the contract on
        prim_exch - the primary exchange to carry out the contract on
        curr - the currency in which to purchase the contract
        '''
        contract = Contract()
        contract.m_symbol = symbol
        contract.m_secType = sec_type
        contract.m_exchange = exch
        contract.m_primaryExch = prim_exch
        contract.m_currency = curr
        return contract

    def create_order(self, order_type, quantity, action):
        ''' Create an Order object (Market/Limit) to go long/short.

        order_type - 'MKT', 'LMT' for market or limit orders
        quantity - integer number of units to order
        action - 'BUY' or 'SELL'
        '''
        order = Order()
        order.m_orderType = order_type
        order.m_totalQuantity = quantity
        order.m_action = action
        return order

    def place_order(self, contract, order):
        ''' Place the order for a given contract via TWS
        '''
        if not isinstance(contract, Contract):
            raise ValueError('contract must be a Contract object')
        if not isinstance(order, Order):
            raise ValueError('order must be an Order object')

        self.placeOrder(self.next_order_id, contract, order)
        self.next_order_id += 1

    def req_positions(self):
        ''' Wrapper to request from TWS a list of positions
        '''
        self.reqPositions()

    def req_contract_details(self, contract):
        ''' Wrapper to request from TWS details of a contract
        '''
        if not isinstance(contract, Contract):
            raise ValueError('contract must be a Contract object')
        self.reqContractDetails(1, contract)

    # setter and getter methods

    def set_next_order_id(self, order_id):
        ''' Sets the next order id, either when creating a new connection
        or when sending an open order
        '''
        self.next_order_id = order_id

    def get_next_order_id(self):
        return self.next_order_id

    def get_market_data_once(self, contract):
        ''' Sends a one time request for market data for a contract
        '''
        self.print_once.add(self.next_data_request_id)
        self.reqMktData(self.next_data_request_id, contract, '', True)
        self.next_data_request_id += 1

    def request_market_data(self, contract, callback=None):
        ''' Sends a market data request for a contract to TWS,
        the response is streamed to the callback function until
        the request is canceled with self.cancel_market_data(request_id);
        if no callback is given, the results will be printed;
        returns the request_id
        '''
        self.tick_callbacks[self.next_data_request_id] = callback
        self.reqMktData(self.next_data_request_id, contract, '', False)
        old = self.next_data_request_id
        self.next_data_request_id += 1
        return old

    def cancel_market_data(self, request_id):
        ''' Cancels a running market data request '''
        self.cancelMktData(request_id)

    def request_historical_data(self, contract, end_date_time, duration,
                                bar_size, what_to_show, use_RTH=True,
                                format_date=1):
        ''' Sends a historical data request for contract to the TWS,
        the response is streamed to the callback function until the request
        is canceld with self.cancel_market_data(request_id);
        returns the request_id
        '''
        if bar_size not in VALID_BAR_SIZES:
            raise ValueError('bar_size must be one of %s' % VALID_BAR_SIZES)
        if type(use_RTH) != bool:
            raise TypeError('use_RTH must be of type bool')
        elif use_RTH is True:
            use_RTH = True
        else:
            use_RTH = False
        if type(end_date_time) != dt.datetime:
            raise TypeError('end_date_time must be of type datetime')
        else:
            end_date_time = end_date_time.strftime('%Y%m%d %X')
        if what_to_show not in WHAT_TO_SHOW:
            raise ValueError('what_to_show must be in %s' % WHAT_TO_SHOW)

        self.reqHistoricalData(self.next_data_request_id, contract,
                               endDateTime=end_date_time, durationStr=duration,
                               barSizeSetting=bar_size, whatToShow=what_to_show,
                               useRTH=False, formatDate=format_date)

        # count request id

        old = self.next_data_request_id
        self.next_data_request_id += 1

        # set loading flag for request id

        self.hist_data_loading[old] = True
        return old

    def get_historical_data(self, request_id, silent=False):
        ''' Returns the historical data for a given request id,
        if silent equal to True, the 'is still loading' message will be ommited
        '''

        if request_id not in self.hist_data_loading:
            # unknown request id
            raise ValueError('No data found for request id %s' % request_id)
        elif self.hist_data_loading[request_id] is True:
            # still loading
            if not silent:
                print("Historical data for request id %s still loading" %
                      request_id)
            return False
        else:
            return self.hist_data[request_id]

    def is_historical_data_loading(self, request_id):
        ''' Returns True if the request with id request_id is still loading
        and False else
        '''
        if request_id not in self.hist_data_loading:
            # unknown request id
            raise ValueError('No data found for request id %s' % request_id)
        elif self.hist_data_loading[request_id] is True:
            # still loading
            return True
        else:
            return False

    # callback functions for requests to TWS

    def on_contract_details(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for connections
        '''
        summary = msg.contractDetails.m_summary
        templ = 'Symbol: %s, Type: %s, Exchange: %s, Primary Exchange: %s,'
        templ += 'Currency: %s'
        out = templ % (summary.m_symbol, summary.m_secType, summary.m_exchange,
                       summary.m_primaryExch, summary.m_currency)
        print(out)

    def on_position_request(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for position requests
        '''
        con = msg.contract
        pos = msg.pos
        avgCost = msg.avgCost
        templ = 'Quantity: %s, Symbol: %s, Currency: %s, Average Cost: %s'
        out = templ % (pos, con.m_symbol, con.m_currency, avgCost)
        print(out)

    def on_account_summary(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for account summary
        '''
        print('%s: %s' % (msg.tag, msg.value))

    def on_open_order(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for open orders
        '''
        con = msg.contract
        order = msg.order
        if msg.orderId not in self.reported_orders:
            self.reported_orders.add(msg.orderId)
            print('Order: %s %s %s' %
                  (order.m_action, order.m_totalQuantity, con.m_symbol))

    def on_order_status(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for order status
        '''
        print('    Filled: %s, Status: %s' % (msg.filled, msg.status))

    def on_commission_report(self, msg):
        pass

    def on_connection_closed(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for closing connection
        '''
        print('Bye.')

    def on_next_order_id(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for next order id requests
        '''
        self.set_next_order_id(msg.orderId)

    def on_tick(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for market data requests
        '''
        tick_id = msg.tickerId
        if msg.typeName == 'tickSize':
            field_name = TickType.getField(msg.field)
            value = msg.size
        elif msg.typeName == 'tickPrice':
            field_name = TickType.getField(msg.field)
            value = msg.price
        elif msg.typeName in ['tickGeneric', 'tickString']:
            field_name = TickType.getField(msg.tickType)
            value = msg.value

        if tick_id in self.print_once:
            if tick_id not in self.ticker_data:
                ticker_data = dict()
            else:
                ticker_data = self.ticker_data[tick_id]

            ticker_data[field_name] = value
            self.ticker_data[tick_id] = ticker_data
        elif tick_id in self.tick_callbacks:
            self.tick_callbacks[tick_id](field_name, value)

    def on_snapshot_end(self, msg):
        tick_id = msg.reqId
        tick_data = self.ticker_data[tick_id]
        timestamp = str(dt.datetime.fromtimestamp(int(tick_data['lastTimestamp'])))
        tick_string = 'Last timestamp: %s, Ask price: %s, Ask size: %s,'
        tick_string += 'Bid price: %s, Bid size: %s, Low: %s, '
        tick_string += 'High: %s, Close: %s, Volume: %s, Last price: %s,'
        tick_string += 'Last size: %s, Halted: %s'
        tick_string = tick_string % (timestamp,
                        tick_data['askPrice'], tick_data['askSize'],
                        tick_data['bidPrice'], tick_data['bidSize'],
                        tick_data['low'], tick_data['high'], tick_data['close'],
                        tick_data['volume'], tick_data['lastPrice'],
                        tick_data['lastSize'], tick_data['halted'])
        print(tick_string)

    def on_hist_data(self, msg):
        data_id = msg.reqId
        # columns = msg.keys()
        new_data = dict()
        for item in msg.items():
            if item[0] != 'reqId':
                if item[0] == 'date':
                    date = item[1]
                    if date[:8] == 'finished':
                        self.hist_data[data_id] = self.hist_data[
                            data_id].set_index('date')
                        self.hist_data_loading[data_id] = False
                        return True
                    elif len(date) == 8:
                        value = dt.datetime(
                            int(date[:4]), int(date[4:6]), int(date[6:]))
                    else:
                        time = date[9:].split(":")
                        value = dt.datetime(int(date[:4]), int(date[4:6]), int(
                          date[6:8]), int(time[0]), int(time[1]), int(time[2]))
                else:
                    value = item[1]

                new_data[item[0]] = value
        if data_id not in self.hist_data:
            temp_data = pd.DataFrame([new_data])
        else:
            temp_data = self.hist_data[data_id].append(
                new_data, ignore_index=True)
        self.hist_data[data_id] = temp_data

    def error_handler(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for errors
        '''
        if hasattr(msg, 'id') and msg.id in self.hist_data_loading:
            self.hist_data_loading[int(msg.id)] = False
            self.hist_data[int(msg.id)] = pd.DataFrame()

        print('Server Error: %s' % msg.errorMsg)

    def reply_handler(self, msg):
        ''' Callback for all other messages
        '''
        if msg.typeName not in EXCLUDE:
            print('Server Response: %s, %s' % (msg.typeName, msg))

10. Trading Cryptocurrencies with Gemini

Bitcoin is the beginning of something great: a currency without a government, something necessary and imperative.

Nassim Nicholas Taleb

10.1. Introduction

In recent years, digital currencies, like Bitcoin, and the technologies that enable them, like blockchain, have gained much traction in the financial industry and beyond. Good introductions to these topics are Antonopoulos (2014) and Narayanan et al. (2016). For a Python-based introduction into major concepts watch the video Hashing, Encryption, Blockchain & Bitcoin Mining with Python.

The Bitcoin mining process ensures that the number of Bitcoins created over time grows almost linearly as shown in Number of Bitcoins in existence (millions).

In [1]: import quandl as q  (1)

In [2]: bn = q.get('BCHAIN/TOTBC') / 1e6  (2)

In [3]: bn.plot(figsize=(10, 6))  (3)
1 Import the Quandl Python package.
2 Retrieves the number of Bitcoins in existence as a time series and scales it to millions USD.
3 Plots the data.
Figure 65. Number of Bitcoins in existence (millions)

In 2016, the Bitcoin exchange rate versus the USD saw a major rally from about 400 USD to above 1,000 USD at the beginning of 2017it has been the best performing currency of 2016.[33] In 2017 it seems set to reach the high of close to 1,200 USD as seen towards the end of 2013. Bitcoin exchange rate in USD shows the exchange rate since its inception in 2009.

In [4]: be = q.get('BCHAIN/MKPRU')  (1)

In [5]: be.plot(figsize=(10, 6))
1 Retrieves exchange rate time series data.
Figure 66. Bitcoin exchange rate in USD

With regard to market capitalization, Bitcoin has reached new highs since the end of 2016getting for the first time above 15 billion USDand seems to be on its way towards 20 billion USD (see Bitcoin market capitalization in billion USD). This is still tiny compared to other established currencies (fiat money), like USD, GBP or EUR, but it shows the growing importance of cryptocurrencies among which Bitcoin is by far the biggest in terms of market capitalization.[34] Another cryptocurrency that has gained popularity is Ether which is based on the Ethereum blockchain protocol.

In [6]: bm = q.get('BCHAIN/MKTCP') / 1e9  (1)

In [7]: bm.plot(figsize=(10, 6))
1 Retrieves market capitalization time series data and scales it to billions USD.
Figure 67. Bitcoin market capitalization in billion USD

Bitcoin trading is possible on different specialized platforms. This chapter introduces Geminisee Gemini cryptocurrency trading platform as one of the more important players with good application programming interfaces (APIs) available for automated, algorithmic trading. Gemini describes itself on its home page as follows:

The next generation digital asset platform built for businesses and investors. Buy, sell, and store both bitcoin and ether with superior trading features, security, and regulatory oversight.

Figure 68. Gemini cryptocurrency trading platform

Again, we use the criteria for broker selection as outlined in CFD Trading with Oanda to briefly characterizes Gemini as an online trading platform. BTC and ETH stand for Bitcoin and Ether, respectively.

  • instruments: on the Gemini platform, you can trade three different trading pairs: BTC/USD, ETH/USD, ETH/BTC

  • strategies: Gemini allows the buying and selling of BTC and ETH based on different order types (e.g. market, limit); all trades must be fully funded in advance ("full reserve exchange")

  • costs: the platform features a detailed fee schedule where the fee for smaller, liquidity-taking trades is 0.25% (25 basis points [bps]) on the value of the trade; there are different discounts available depending on trading behavior and volume

  • technology: Gemini provides a modern RESTful API for historical data, streaming data, order book data, account data or order placement; in the documentation, Gemini provides examples of how to work with the API based on Python (see Gemini API documentation)

  • jurisdiction: live accounts for Gemini are not available in every country/jurisdiction; however, sandbox account might be opened even from such countries where live trading is not (yet) possible

Figure 69. Gemini API documentation

There are some benefits worth mentioning with regard to cryptocurrency trading compared to stock/options trading or CFD trading, for example:

low capital requirements

the capital requirements to trade cryptocurrencies are quite low so that even students and academics can get started with real, live algorithmic trading without much capital

state-of-the-art technology

almost all players in the field are rather new and employ modern (web) technologies throughout; the whole field of cryptocurrencies is quite technology-driven which plays in the hands of algorithmic traders

24/7 trading

regular financial markets have opening hours that span only a fraction of the day in general and are often closed during weekends; cryptocurrency markets are open around the clock, making continuous tradingwithout special effects during opening and closing timespossible

full transparency

cryptocurrency exchanges and trading platforms generally provide full information about the order book so that every trader has full transparency of the market activity

These benefits make cryptocurrencies attractive as an entry point to algorithmic trading. The 24/7 trading and the full transparency make it also interesting for institutional playersin addition to the fact, that such digital assets represent a new asset class with distinct characteristics.

10.2. Setting Up an Account

Setting up a sandbox account with Gemini is simple and can be done under Gemini sandbox registration (see Gemini sandbox account registration). You should make sure to choose a location (residency) where Gemini provides real trading accounts as well (like, for example, the United Kingdom). A mobile number is also to be provided for two way authentication.

Figure 70. Gemini sandbox account registration

In what follows, it is expected that the credentials are stored in the pyalgo.cfg configuration file as follows:

[gemini]
key = YOUR_API_KEY
secret_key = YOUR_SECRET_API_KEY
url = https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/

Setting up a sandbox account with Gemini is simple and allows the use of all API functionalities without having a real trading account with real funds. However, make sure to choose a resident country in which Gemini also offers real trading accounts.

10.3. A Wrapper Class for the Gemini API

Python wrapper class for Gemini API provides a Python wrapper class for the Gemini API which makes interacting with the API really efficient and convenient. The class code contains also detailed docstrings which replicate in larger parts documentation texts from the Gemini API documentation for better understanding. The following code shows how to instantiate a connection object based on the class pygem and retrieves as a test the list of traded symbols (currency pairs).

In [1]: import pygem  (1)

In [2]: from pygem import config  (2)

In [3]: con = pygem.pygem(config['gemini']['key'],
                          config['gemini']['secret_key'],
                          debug=True)  (3)

In [4]: res = con.get_symbols()  (4)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/symbols

In [5]: res  (5)
Out[5]: ['btcusd', 'ethbtc', 'ethusd']
1 Imports the module with the main class pygem.
2 Imports the credentials object based on the pyalgo.cfg configurations file.
3 Instantiates a connection object based on the main class.
4 Retrieves the symbols traded on the Gemini platform and
5 prints them.

Being connected to the Gemini API, allows you to also retrieve the current ticker information.

In [6]: con.get_ticker('btcusd')  (1)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/pubticker/btcusd
Out[6]: {'ask': '907.01',
         'bid': '906.71',
         'last': '906.75',
         'volume': {'BTC': '462.00355504',
          'USD': '416800.1339967712',
          'timestamp': 1483962000000}}

In [7]: con.get_ticker('ethusd')  (2)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/pubticker/ethusd
Out[7]: {'ask': '10.78',
         'bid': '10.77',
         'last': '10.77',
         'volume': {'ETH': '36275.081049',
          'USD': '380005.44161323',
          'timestamp': 1483962000000}}

In [8]: ticker = con.get_ticker('ethbtc')  (3)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/pubticker/ethbtc

In [9]: ticker  (4)
Out[9]: {'ask': '0.01173',
         'bid': '0.01172',
         'last': '0.01172',
         'volume': {'BTC': '378.36205032532',
          'ETH': '32891.250696',
          'timestamp': 1483962300000}}

In [10]: import datetime as dt

In [11]: dt.datetime.fromtimestamp(int(ticker['volume']['timestamp']) / 1e3)  (5)
Out[11]: datetime.datetime(2017, 1, 9, 12, 45)
1 Retrieves ticker data for BTC/USD.
2 Retrieves ticker data for ETH/USD.
3 Retrieves ticker data for ETH/BTC
4 and shows the data.
5 Transforms the timestamp to a datetime object.

Note that the data retrieved from the sandbox API does not necessarily reflect market and/or exchange realities. The sandbox accounts of Gemini are intended to allow for a risk-free, simple evaluation of the technology and to set everything up for live trading later on.

10.4. Retrieving Historical Data

Retrieving detailed historical trade information made simple by the use of the get_trades_history method. Price and volume data for 500 Bitcoin trades on 09. January 2017 from 11am UK time shows the data graphically for 500 trades from 09. January 2017.

In [6]: import datetime as dt

In [7]: data = con.get_trades_history('btcusd',  (1)
                                      since=dt.datetime(2017, 1, 9, 11, 0, 0),  (2)
                                      limit_trades=500,  (3)
                                      include_breaks=False) (4)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/trades/btcusd?since=1483920000000&include_breaks=false&limit_trades=200

In [8]: data.info()  (5)
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
DatetimeIndex: 500 entries, 2017-01-09 01:34:38 to 2017-01-09 01:00:03
Data columns (total 7 columns):
amount         500 non-null float64
exchange       500 non-null object
price          500 non-null float64
tid            500 non-null int64
timestamp      500 non-null int64
timestampms    500 non-null int64
type           500 non-null object
dtypes: float64(2), int64(3), object(2)
memory usage: 31.2+ KB

In [9]: data.tail()  (6)
                    amount  exch.   price   tid         timestamp   timestampms     type
datetime
2017-01-09 12:16:01 0.002   gemini  901.62  74597853    1483960561  1483960561740   buy
2017-01-09 12:16:03 0.001   gemini  901.62  74597869    1483960563  1483960563530   buy
2017-01-09 12:16:05 0.002   gemini  901.62  74597883    1483960565  1483960565035   buy
2017-01-09 12:16:05 0.001   gemini  901.62  74597890    1483960565  1483960565632   buy
2017-01-09 12:16:06 0.001   gemini  901.62  74597897    1483960566  1483960566031   buy

In [10]: data[['price', 'amount']].plot(secondary_y='amount', figsize=(10, 6))
1 Retrieves the trade history for BTC/USD
2 for the 9. January 2017, from 11 am UK time,
3 limits the number of trades to 500 (which is the maximum anyways) and
4 excludes broken trades.
5 The wrapper class transforms the raw data by default to a DataFrame object.
6 The final five data rows from the DataFrame object.
Figure 71. Price and volume data for 500 Bitcoin trades on 09. January 2017 from 11am UK time

Order book data is also accessible at any time via the get_current_order_book method.

In [10]: order = con.get_current_order_book('btcusd',  (1)
                                            limit_asks=5,  (2)
                                            limit_bids=5)  (3)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/book/btcusd?limit_bids=5&limit_asks=5

In [11]: import pprint  (4)

In [12]: pprint.pprint(order)  (5)
{'asks': [{'amount': '0.73267397', 'price': '907.02', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '3.22', 'price': '907.06', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.01378985', 'price': '907.08', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.342436', 'price': '907.10', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.843', 'price': '907.15', 'timestamp': '1483962806'}],
 'bids': [{'amount': '0.59913323', 'price': '907.01', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.002', 'price': '906.68', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.002', 'price': '906.62', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.001', 'price': '906.59', 'timestamp': '1483962806'},
          {'amount': '0.002', 'price': '906.56', 'timestamp': '1483962806'}]}
1 Retrieves current order book data for BTC/USD and
2 limits the number of asks to 5 and
3 the number of bids to 5, respectively.
4 Imports the pretty printing module.
5 Prints the order book data.

From the order book data you can, for example, get a detailed overview of the frequency of the bid prices.

In [13]: order = con.get_current_order_book('btcusd',
                                            limit_asks=500,
                                            limit_bids=500)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/book/btcusd?limit_bids=500&limit_asks=500

In [14]: import pandas as pd

In [15]: bids = pd.DataFrame(order['bids'])  (1)

In [16]: bids['price'].astype(float).hist(bins=50, figsize=(10, 6))  (2)
1 Creates a DataFrame object from the bid data sub-set.
2 Plots a histogram of the bid prices.
Figure 72. Frequency distribution of the Bitcoin bid prices in USD in the order book during a day in January 2017

10.5. Placing and Managing Orders via the API

To implement automated, algorithmic trading strategies, the ability to programmatically place buy and sell orders is key. The pygem class supports with this as well. The following code places first a limit buy order with a high enough price to get it executed in any case (well above the then current Bitcoin price). It also places an order with a price below the then current Bitcoin price.

In [17]: new_order_result_1 = con.new_order(symbol='btcusd', amount=0.001,
                                            price=1000, side='buy')  (1)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/order/new
Payload:  {"nonce": "14840414264450050048", "amount": "0.001", "symbol": "btcusd", "side": "buy", "type": "exchange limit", "request": "/v1/order/new", "price": "1000.0"}

In [18]: new_order_result_1  (2)
Out[18]: {'avg_execution_price': '0.00',
          'exchange': 'gemini',
          'executed_amount': '0',
          'id': '75162062',
          'is_cancelled': False,
          'is_hidden': False,
          'is_live': True,
          'order_id': '75162062',
          'original_amount': '0.001',
          'price': '1000.00',
          'remaining_amount': '0.001',
          'side': 'buy',
          'symbol': 'btcusd',
          'timestamp': '1484041427',
          'timestampms': 1484041427337,
          'type': 'exchange limit',
          'was_forced': False}

In [18]: new_order_result_2 = con.new_order(symbol='btcusd', amount=0.0001,
                                            price=900, side='buy')  (3)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/order/new
Payload:  {"nonce": "14840418723577749504", "amount": "0.0001", "symbol": "btcusd", "side": "buy", "type": "exchange limit", "request": "/v1/order/new", "price": "900.0"}

In [19]: new_order_result_2
Out[19]: {'avg_execution_price': '0.00',
          'exchange': 'gemini',
          'executed_amount': '0',
          'id': '75162932',
          'is_cancelled': False,
          'is_hidden': False,
          'is_live': True,
          'order_id': '75162932',
          'original_amount': '0.0001',
          'price': '900.00',
          'remaining_amount': '0.0001',
          'side': 'buy',
          'symbol': 'btcusd',
          'timestamp': '1484041873',
          'timestampms': 1484041873190,
          'type': 'exchange limit',
          'was_forced': False}
1 Places the first order at a high price (well above the then current price)
2 and shows the confirmation as retrieved from the API.
3 Places the second order at a relatively low price (slightly below the then current price); only gets fulfilled if the Bitcoin price in USD drops below the limit price.

Gemini places lots of emphasis on security. One of the measures is that you receive an email confirming the order placement. Here the confirmation for the first order:

Hi Yves Hilpisch,

Success! Your limit buy order for 0.001 BTC at $1,000.00 per BTC has been placed. If your order gets filled, you will receive another confirmation email.

Order Date: January 10, 2017 09:43:47 UTC
Order Type: Limit Buy
Order ID: 75162062

Amount: 0.001 BTC
Price: $1,000.00 per BTC

Subtotal: $1.00
Fee: $0.01
Total: $1.01

If you did not initiate this transaction, or if you wish to dispute this order, you must contact us at support@gemini.com or +1 (866) 240-5113 within three (3) days.

Onward and upward,

Team Gemini

And the one for the second order:

Hi Yves Hilpisch,

Success! Your limit buy order for 0.0001 BTC at $900.00 per BTC has been placed. If your order gets filled, you will receive another confirmation email.

Order Date: January 10, 2017 09:51:13 UTC
Order Type: Limit Buy
Order ID: 75162932

Amount: 0.0001 BTC
Price: $900.00 per BTC

Subtotal: $0.09
Fee: $0.01
Total: $0.10

If you did not initiate this transaction, or if you wish to dispute this order, you must contact us at support@gemini.com or +1 (866) 240-5113 within three (3) days.

Onward and upward,

Team Gemini

As long as the order are not executed, you can see them in your account under Open Orders as shown in Open orders in the Gemini sandbox account.

Figure 73. Open orders in the Gemini sandbox account

Once an order gets filled, another email is sent by Gemini confirming it. As you can see in the confirmation, the total cash in USD spent is only 1 and the fee is 0.01 dollar cents.

Hi Yves Hilpisch,

Success! Your limit buy order for 0.001 BTC at $1,000.00 per BTC has been filled.

Order Date: January 10, 2017 09:43:47 UTC
Order Filled: January 10, 2017 10:06:44 UTC
Order Type: Limit Buy
Individual Trades: 1
Order ID: 75162062

Amount: 0.001 BTC
Price: $1,000.00 per BTC

Subtotal: $1.00
Fee: $0.01
Total: $1.01

If you did not initiate this transaction, or if you wish to dispute this order, you must contact us at support@gemini.com or +1 (866) 240-5113 within three (3) days.

Onward and upward,

Team Gemini

The status of open orders can be checked via the API as well. Similarly, an open order can be canceled via the API.

In [20]: order_id = new_order_result_2['order_id']  (1)

In [21]: status = con.get_order_status(order_id)  (2)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/order/status
Payload:  {"order_id": "75162932", "nonce": "14840433908499998720", "request": "/v1/order/status"}

In [22]: status  (3)
In [22]: {'avg_execution_price': '0.00',
          'exchange': 'gemini',
          'executed_amount': '0',
          'id': '75162932',
          'is_cancelled': False,
          'is_hidden': False,
          'is_live': True,
          'order_id': '75162932',
          'original_amount': '0.0001',
          'price': '900.00',
          'remaining_amount': '0.0001',
          'side': 'buy',
          'symbol': 'btcusd',
          'timestamp': '1484041873',
          'timestampms': 1484041873190,
          'type': 'exchange limit',
          'was_forced': False}

In [23]: # orders = con.get_active_orders() (4)

In [24]: cancel = con.cancel_order(order_id)  (5)
URL:  https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/order/cancel
Payload:  {"order_id": "75162932", "nonce": "14840436413132720128", "request": "/v1/order/cancel"}

In [25]: cancel  (6)
Out[25]: {'avg_execution_price': '0.00',
          'exchange': 'gemini',
          'executed_amount': '0',
          'id': '75162932',
          'is_cancelled': True,
          'is_hidden': False,
          'is_live': False,
          'order_id': '75162932',
          'original_amount': '0.0001',
          'price': '900.00',
          'remaining_amount': '0.0001',
          'side': 'buy',
          'symbol': 'btcusd',
          'timestamp': '1484041873',
          'timestampms': 1484041873190,
          'type': 'exchange limit',
          'was_forced': False}

In [25]: # cancel = con.cancel_all_session_orders()   (7)
1 Picks the order_id for the second order.
2 Retrieves the status information for the order
3 and shows it.
4 Alternatively, the get_active_orders method retrieves status information for all open orders.
5 Cancels the order and
6 and shows the result ('is_cancelled': True).
7 Alternatively, all open orders of a session can be canceled at once via the cancel_all_session_orders method.

After cancellation, Gemini sends again an email confirmation:

Hi Yves Hilpisch,

Your limit buy order for 0.0001 BTC at $900.00 per BTC has been canceled.

If you did not initiate this transaction, or if you wish to dispute this order, you must contact us at support@gemini.com or +1 (866) 240-5113 within three (3) days.

Onward and upward,

Team Gemini

In the sandbox account, you find information about the to transactions (one order filled, the other canceled) under Transaction History (see Transaction history in Gemini sandbox account).

Figure 74. Transaction history in Gemini sandbox account

Gemini places heavy emphasis on security. For example, it requires a two-way authentication process using a regular login in combination with a pass code sent to your mobile phone (see Two way authentication with pass code via text message to mobile). It also notifies you by email about every important account activity.
Figure 75. Two way authentication with pass code via text message to mobile

10.6. Most Recent Transaction History

The first step in automatically trading in real-time is to get real-time information from the API. This can be achieved, for example, via the get_trades_history method and pulling the trades history in regular time intervals.

In [1]: import pygem

In [2]: from pygem import config

In [3]: con = pygem.pygem(config['gemini']['key'],
                          config['gemini']['secret_key'],
                          debug=False)  (1)

In [4]: since = dt.datetime.now() - dt.timedelta(hours=1.1)  (2)

In [5]: import time

In [6]: for i in range(12):
            trades = con.get_trades_history('ethusd', since=since,
                                            limit_trades=500, include_breaks=False)  (3)
            print(40 * '-')
            print('timestamp %s' % dt.datetime.fromtimestamp(
                                    float(trades['timestamp'].ix[-1])))  (4)
            print('#   trades: %d' % len(trades))  (5)
            print('ave. price: %f' % float(trades['price'].mean()))  (6)
            print('min  price: %f' % float(trades['price'].min()))  (7)
            print('max  price: %f' % float(trades['price'].max()))  (8)
            print('last price: %f' % float(trades['price'].ix[-1]))  (9)
            time.sleep(5)  (10)
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:26:59
#   trades: 106
ave. price: 10.481038
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:26:59
#   trades: 106  (11)
ave. price: 10.481038
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:27:16
#   trades: 114  (12)
ave. price: 10.479561
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:27:20
#   trades: 116
ave. price: 10.479224
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:27:25
#   trades: 120
ave. price: 10.478583
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
----------------------------------------
timestamp 2017-01-10 12:27:32
#   trades: 122
ave. price: 10.478279
min  price: 10.460000
max  price: 10.500000
last price: 10.460000
1 This time, the debug flag is set to False.
2 Sets the time window a bit more than an hour.
3 Retrieves the maximum number of trades of Ether for the time window.
4 Print the last available timestamp.
5 Shows the number of trades in the DataFrame object.
6 Prints the average price from all trades
7 The minimum price.
8 The maximum price.
9 And the last available price.
10 Waits for 5 seconds.
11 No new trades.
12 New trades are included.

Although this works in principle, the better way is using the Geminis web socket API which is shown in the next section.

10.7. Implementing Trading Strategies in Real-Time

First, a simple example of how to retrieve, collect and resample tick data for the BTC/USD pair. At the core is the on_message function which defines what to do with the data set retrieved via the socket. In line with the Gemini documentation, the example below uses the websocket module from the Python standard library.

In [1]: import json  (1)

In [2]: import pandas as pd

In [3]: data = pd.DataFrame()  (2)

In [4]: messages = []  (3)

In [5]: def on_message(ws, message):
            global data  (4)
            global resam  (4)
            timestamp = dt.datetime.now()  (5)
            msg = json.loads(message)  (6)
            try:
                side = msg['events'][0]['side']  (7)
                price = float(msg['events'][0]['price'])  (8)
                if msg['type'] == 'update':  (9)
                    print('%s | %s price = %f' % (timestamp, side, price))  (10)
                    data = data.append(pd.DataFrame({side: price},
                                       index=[timestamp]))  (11)
                    messages.append(message)  (12)
                    resam = data.resample('5s').last().ffill()  (13)
                    resam['mid'] = resam.mean(axis=1)  (14)
            except:
                pass
1 Import the json module to transform text messages into dict objects.
2 Instantiates a new DataFrame object for the tick data.
3 Instantiates an empty list object to collect the text messages.
4 Defines the global variables for data collection.
5 Records a timestamp value.
6 Transforms the text message to a dict object.
7 Picks the side of the transaction (bid or ask).
8 Picks the price for the BTC/USD pair.
9 Selects certain message types.
10 Prints timestamp, side, price.
11 Appends the new tick data to the DataFrame object.
12 Appends the text message to the list object.
13 Resamples the tick data to a five second interval.
14 Calculates mid-price points between bid and ask prices.

This function alone does not do anything. However, in combination with a socket connection to the Gemini API, it shows its capabilities.

In [6]: import websocket  (1)

In [7]: ws = websocket.WebSocketApp('wss://api.gemini.com/v1/marketdata/BTCUSD',
                                    on_message=on_message)  (2)

In [8]: ws.run_forever(ping_interval=5)  (3)
...
2017-01-11 12:45:14.605230 | bid price = 804.620000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.029564 | bid price = 834.210000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.035579 | bid price = 833.700000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.095708 | ask price = 847.490000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.110234 | ask price = 844.080000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.168822 | ask price = 843.870000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.250911 | bid price = 837.830000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.267525 | ask price = 844.490000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.320955 | bid price = 837.830000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.345908 | ask price = 844.010000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.431703 | ask price = 844.880000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.527795 | ask price = 844.400000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.590530 | bid price = 825.380000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.642591 | bid price = 824.910000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.723908 | bid price = 822.900000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.786832 | bid price = 822.430000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.855942 | ask price = 846.910000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.909559 | ask price = 846.430000
2017-01-11 12:45:15.983058 | ask price = 848.850000
2017-01-11 12:45:16.046963 | ask price = 848.250000
2017-01-11 12:45:16.100729 | bid price = 837.920000
2017-01-11 12:45:16.356002 | bid price = 806.000000
2017-01-11 12:45:16.442509 | bid price = 806.810000
...
1 Imports the websocket module.
2 Connects to the Gemini web socket API via the wss protocol.
3 Starts the connection and runs it until interrupted.

During the execution and thereafter, one can access the DataFrame objects storing the tick data and the resampled data, respectively. It is obvious that the bid-ask spread can be significant.

In [9]: data.tail()  (1)
Out[9]:
                            ask bid
2017-01-11 12:51:51.700220  NaN 807.72
2017-01-11 12:51:51.812274  NaN 805.93
2017-01-11 12:51:51.895677  NaN 807.23
2017-01-11 12:51:52.059027  NaN 805.46
2017-01-11 12:51:52.110015  NaN 806.59

In [10]: resam.tail()  (2)
Out[10]:
                    ask     bid     mid
2017-01-11 12:51:30 843.89  837.84  840.865
2017-01-11 12:51:35 845.44  834.42  839.930
2017-01-11 12:51:40 845.44  837.85  841.645
2017-01-11 12:51:45 842.81  835.80  839.305
2017-01-11 12:51:50 842.81  806.59  824.700
1 Final five rows of the tick data and
2 the resampled data.

TO BE COMPLETED: This section is not yet complete. We are going to provide a wrapper class for the web socket API of Gemini as well. Based on this class, a real-time algorithmic strategy will be illustrated.

10.8. Retrieving Account Information

Using the pygem wrapper class, retrieving account information is as simple as retrieving historical trades.

In [1]: con = pygem.pygem(config['gemini']['key'],
                          config['gemini']['secret_key'],
                          debug=False)

In [2]: balances = con.get_available_balances()  (1)

In [3]: balances  (2)
Out[3]: [{'amount': '1001.031',
          'available': '1001.031',
          'availableForWithdrawal': '1001.031',
          'currency': 'BTC',
          'type': 'exchange'},
         {'amount': '99075.55',
          'available': '99075.55',
          'availableForWithdrawal': '99075.55',
          'currency': 'USD',
          'type': 'exchange'},
         {'amount': '20000',
          'available': '20000',
          'availableForWithdrawal': '20000',
          'currency': 'ETH',
          'type': 'exchange'}]

In [4]: volumes = con.get_trade_volume()  (3)

In [4]: volumes  (4)
Out[4]: [[...,
         {'account_id': 366,
          'base_currency': 'BTC',
          'buy_maker_base': 0.62,
          'buy_maker_count': 3,
          'buy_maker_notional': 558.0,
          'buy_taker_base': 0,
          'buy_taker_count': 0,
          'buy_taker_notional': 0,
          'data_date': '2017-01-06',
          'maker_buy_sell_ratio': 1,
          'notional_currency': 'USD',
          'sell_maker_base': 0,
          'sell_maker_count': 0,
          'sell_maker_notional': 0,
          'sell_taker_base': 0,
          'sell_taker_count': 0,
          'sell_taker_notional': 0,
          'symbol': 'btcusd',
          'total_volume_base': 0.62},
         {'account_id': 366,
          'base_currency': 'BTC',
          'buy_maker_base': 0.001,
          'buy_maker_count': 1,
          'buy_maker_notional': 1.0,
          'buy_taker_base': 0,
          'buy_taker_count': 0,
          'buy_taker_notional': 0,

          'sell_maker_base': 0,
          'sell_maker_count': 0,
          'sell_maker_notional': 0,
          'sell_taker_base': 0,
          'sell_taker_count': 0,
          'sell_taker_notional': 0,

         ...]]

In [5]: orders = con.get_active_orders()  (5)

In [6]: orders  (6)
Out[6]: []
1 Retrieves current balance information and
2 prints it.
3 Retrieves trading volume information and
4 prints it.
5 Checks the currently active order
6 which in this case returns an empty list object.

10.9. Conclusions

Cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology are a fascinating filed in technology these days. Furthermore, cryptocurrencies represent a new, digital asset class that can be traded quite easily in automated, algorithmic fashion. To this end, the Gemini trading platform provides both a RESTful API as well as a web socket API for which this chapter introduces Python wrapper classes for more convenience and efficiency.

Algorithmic trading of cryptocurrencies offers a nice entrance to the field since the technology of the platforms and exchanges is state-of-the-art, the capital requirements are rather low and the trading takes place 24/7 with full transparency of the order book. In that sense, the field allows to get started even out of (academic) curiosity without putting up and/or risking larger sums of capital.

10.10. Further Resources

Books cited in this chapter:

  • Antonopoulos, Andreas (2014): Mastering BitcoinUnlocking Digital Cryptocurrencies. OReilly, Bejing et al.

  • Narayanan, Arvind et al. (2016): Bitcoin and Cryptocurrency TechnologiesA Comprehensive Introduction. Princeton University Press, Princeton and Oxford.

10.11. Python Scripts

Example 23. Python wrapper class for Gemini API
#
# Python Wrapper Class for
# Gemini API
# by Michael Schwed
#
# Python for Algorithmic Trading
# (c) Dr. Yves J. Hilpisch
# The Python Quants GmbH
#
# Larger parts of the  docstring texts taken
# from the official Gemini API documentation under
# https://docs.gemini.com/rest-api/
#
import hmac
import hashlib
import time
import base64
import json
import requests
import pandas as pd
import datetime as dt
import configparser

config = configparser.ConfigParser()
config.read('../pyalgo.cfg')


class pygem(object):
    ''' A python wrapper for the gemini API '''

    def __init__(self, key, secret_key, sandbox=True, debug=False):
        '''
        Creates a pygem object, providing methods for all https requests
        in the Gemini API

        Parameter:
        key (string): Gemini API key, can be created on the account site
            of the Gemini pages.
        secret_key (string): Gemini API secret key, can also be created on
            the account site of the Gemini pages.
        sandbox (bool): Wheter to use the sandbox (True) or the live account.
            Default is True.
        debug (bool): If true, the called URLs are printed; default is False.
        '''
        self.key = key
        self.secret_key = secret_key
        if sandbox:
            self.url = 'https://api.sandbox.gemini.com/v1/'
        else:
            self.url = 'https://api.gemini.com/v1/'
        self.last_order_id = None
        self.debug = debug

    def send_public_request(self, method, **kwargs):
        ''' Sends all public request to the Gemini server.
        '''
        url = self.url + method
        paras = list()
        for key in kwargs:
            paras.append('%s=%s' % (key, kwargs[key]))
        if len(paras) is not 0:
            paras_string = '&'.join(paras)
            url = url + '?' + paras_string
        if self.debug:
            print('URL: ', url)
        return requests.get(url, timeout=10).json()

    def send_privat_request(self, method, payload):
        ''' Sends all privat requests to the Gemini server.
        '''
        payload['nonce'] = str(int(time.time() * 100000 ** 2))
        payload = json.dumps(payload)

        payload_encode = base64.b64encode(bytearray(payload, 'utf-8'))
        sig = hmac.new(bytearray(self.secret_key, 'utf-8'),
                       payload_encode, hashlib.sha384).hexdigest()
        headers = {'X-GEMINI-APIKEY': self.key,
                   'X-GEMINI-PAYLOAD': payload_encode,
                   'X-GEMINI-SIGNATURE': sig}
        url = self.url + method
        if self.debug:
            print('URL: ', url)
            print('Payload: ', payload)
        return requests.post(url, headers=headers, timeout=10).json()

    # Private requests

    def new_order(self, symbol, amount, price, side, option='',
                  client_order_id=False):
        '''
        Only limit orders are supported at this point.
        All orders on the exchange are 'Good Until Cancel' - they
        will stay active until either completely filled or cancelled.

        If you wish orders to be automatically cancelled when your
        session ends, see the require heartbeat section, or manually
        send the cancel all session orders message.

        Parameters:
        client_order_id (string, optional): A client-specified order id.
            This is only for custom purpose, pygem methods which need an
            order_id as input (as for example cancel_order()) always use
            the Gemini order_id, which can be found in the field
            'order_id' of the return.
        symbol (string): The symbol for the new order
        amount (float): Quoted decimal amount to purchase
        price (float): Quoted decimal amount to spend per unit
        side (string): 'buy' or 'sell'
        type (string): The order type. Only 'exchange limit' supported
            through this API
        option (string, optional): An optional order execution option.
            If not given, your order will be a standard limit order,
            it will immediately fill against any open orders at an equal
            or better price, then the remainder of the order will be posted
            to the order book.

            The available limit order options are:
            'maker-or-cancel': This order will only add liquidity to the
                order book. If any part of the order could be filled
                immediately, the whole order will instead be canceled before
                any execution occurs. If that happens, the response back
                from the API will indicate that the order has already been
                canceled ('is_cancelled': True).
            'immediate-or-cancel': This order will only remove liquidity
                from the order book. It will fill whatever part of the
                order it can immediately, then cancel any remaining amount
                so that no part of the order is added to the order book.
                If the order doesn't fully fill immediately, the response
                back from the API will indicate that the order has already
                been canceled ('is_cancelled': True).
            'auction-only': This order will be added to the auction-only
                book for the next auction for this symbol. The order will
                not show up on the public API Current Order Book.
                The order will show up in the private API Get Active Orders
                endpoint. The exchange will cancel any unfilled auction-only
                orders at the end of the auction. The order may be cancelled
                up until the the auction locks, after which cancel requests
                will be rejected.

        Result:
        Result will be the same fields as returned by get_order_status()
        '''
        method = 'order/new'
        params = {'request': '/v1/order/new',
                  'symbol': symbol,
                  'type': 'exchange limit'}
        try:
            amount = float(amount)
        except:
            raise TypeError('amount must be a number')
        try:
            price = float(price)
        except:
            raise TypeError('price must be a number')
        if side not in ['buy', 'sell']:
            raise ValueError('side must be either "buy" or "sell"')

        if option and option not in ['maker-or-cancel',
                                     'immediate-or-cancel',
                                     'auction-only']:
            raise ValueError(
                'option must either be empty or one of "maker-or-cancel", \
              "immediate-or-cancel", "auction-only"')

        params['amount'] = str(amount)
        params['price'] = str(price)
        params['side'] = side
        options = list()
        options.append(option)
        if len(option) is not 0:
            params['options'] = options

        if client_order_id is not False:

            if self.last_order_id and not client_order_id > self.last_order_id:
                raise ValueError(
                    'client_order_id is not increasing ( %s !> %s )'
                    % (client_order_id, self.last_order_id))

            self.last_order_id = client_order_id
            params['client_order_id'] = str(client_order_id)

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)
        return res

    def cancel_order(self, order_id):
        '''
        This will cancel an order. If the order is already canceled,
        the message will succeed but have no effect.

        Parameters:
        order_id: The order ID as given in the field 'order_id' of
            the return of new_order().

        Response:
        Result of order_status for the canceled order. If the order
        was already canceled, then the request will have no effect
        and the status will be returned.
        '''
        method = 'order/cancel'
        params = {'request': '/v1/order/cancel',
                  'order_id': str(order_id)}

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)
        return res

    def cancel_all_session_orders(self):
        '''
        This will cancel all orders opened by this session.

        Response:
        The response will be a dictionary with the fields:

        result (str): Will always be 'ok' if the response from the
            Gemini server is 200 OK.
        details (dict): Dictionary with two fields:
            cancelRejects (list): A list with the id's of the orders,
                which are not canceled.
            cancelledOrders (list): A list with the id's of the canceled
                orders.
        '''
        method = 'order/cancel/session'
        params = {'request': '/v1/order/cancel/session'}

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)
        return res

    def cancel_all_active_orders(self):
        '''
        This will cancel all outstanding orders created by all sessions owned
        by this account, including interactive orders placed through the UI.
        Note that this cancels orders that were not placed using this API key.

        Typically cancel_all_session_orders is preferable, so that only orders
        related to the current connected session are cancelled.

        Response:
        The response will be a dictionary with the fields:

        result (str): Will always be 'ok' if the response from the
            Gemini server is 200 OK.
        details (dict): Dictionary with two fields:
            cancelRejects (list): A list with the id's of the orders,
                which are not canceled.
            cancelledOrders (list): A list with the id's of the canceled
                orders.
        '''

        method = 'order/cancel/all'
        params = {'request': '/v1/order/cancel/all'}

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)
        return res

    def get_order_status(self, order_id):
        '''
        Gets the status for an order.

        Parameters:
        order_id: The order id to get information on.

        Response:
        order_id (string): The order id
        client_order_id (string): The optional client-specified
            order id
        symbol (string): The symbol of the order
        exchange (string): Will always be 'gemini'
        price (string): The price the order was issued at
        avg_execution_price (string): The average price at which
            this order as been executed so far.
            0 if the order has not been executed at all.
        side (string): Either 'buy' or 'sell'.
        type (string): Will always be 'exchange limit'
        timestamp (string): The timestamp the order was submitted.
            Note that for compatibility reasons, this is returned
            as a string. We recommend using the timestampms field
            instead.
        timestampms (int): The timestamp the order was submitted in
            milliseconds.
        is_live (bool): True if the order is active on the book (has
            remaining quantity and has not been canceled)
        is_cancelled (bool): True if the order has been canceled.
            Note the spelling, 'cancelled' instead of 'canceled'.
            This is for compatibility reasons.
        was_forced (bool): Will always be False.
        executed_amount (string): The amount of the order that has
            been filled.
        remaining_amount (string): The amount of the order that has
            not been filled.
        original_amount (string): The originally submitted amount of
            the order.
        '''
        method = 'order/status'
        params = {'request': '/v1/order/status',
                  'order_id': str(order_id)}

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)
        return res

    def get_active_orders(self):
        '''
        Gets all live orders.

        Reponse:
        A list of orders status as given by get_order_status()
        for all your live orders.
        '''

        method = 'orders'
        params = {'request': '/v1/orders'}

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)

        return res

    def get_past_trades(self, symbol, limit_trades=50, since=None):
        '''
        Delivers information about your trades in the past.

        Parameters:
        symbol (string): The symbol to retrieve trades for.
        limit_trades (int): The maximum number of trades to return.
            Default is 50, max is 100 (optional).
        since (int or datetime.datetime): Only return trades after
            this timestamp or date (optional).

        Reponse:
        The response will be list of trade information items.

        price (string): The price that the execution happened at.
        amount (string): The quantity that was executed.
        timestamp (int): The time that the trade happened.
        timestampms (int): The time that the trade happened in
            milliseconds.
        type (string): Will be either 'Buy' or 'Sell', indicating
            the side of the original order.
        aggressor (bool): If True, this order was the taker in the trade.
        fee_currency (string): Currency that the fee was paid in.
        fee_amount (string): The amount charged.
        tid (int): Unique identifier for the trade.
        order_id (string): The order that this trade executed against.
        client_order_id (string): The optional client-specified order id
            that this trade is associated with.
        break (string): Will only be present if the trade has been
            reversed (broken).
            The field will contain one of these values:
                'manual': The trade was reversed manually. This means that
                    all fees, proceeds, and debits associated with the trade
                    have been credited or debited to the account seperately.
                    That means that this reported trade must be included for
                    order for the account balance to be correct.
                'full': The trade was fully broken. The reported trade should
                    not be accounted for. It will be as though the transfer
                    of fund associated with the trade had simply not happened.
        '''
        method = 'mytrades'
        params = {'request': '/v1/mytrades',
                  'symbol': symbol}
        try:
            limit_trades = int(limit_trades)
        except:
            raise TypeError('limit_trades must be an integer')

        if since is None:
            since = ''
        elif isinstance(since, dt.date) or isinstance(since, dt.datetime):
            since = self.make_timestamp(since)
        else:
            try:
                since = int(since)
            except:
                raise TypeError('since must be of type datetime.date, \
                                datetime.datetime or an integer')
        params['limit_trades'] = limit_trades
        params['timestamp'] = since

        res = self.send_privat_request(method, params)

        return res

    def get_trade_volume(self):
        '''
        Returns the trade volume.

        Reponse:
        The response will be a nested list of up to 30 days of
        trade volume for each symbol.

           - Each of the inner lists contains the data for one
               symbol.
           - Each inner list item represents 1 day of trading
               volume. All dates are UTC dates.
           - Partial trading volume for the current day is not
               supplied.
           - Days without trading volume will be omitted from
               the array.

        The list items have the following fields:

        account_id (int): Client account id.
        symbol (string): The symbol.
        base_currency (string): Quantity is denominated in this
            currency.
        notional_currency (string): Price is denominated as the
            amount of notional currency per one unit of base currency.
            Notional values are denominated in this currency.
        data_date (string): UTC date in yyyy-MM-dd format.
        total_volume_base (float): Total trade volume for this day.
        maker_buy_sell_ratio (float): Maker buy/sell ratio is the
            proportion of maker base volume on trades where the account
            was on the buy side versus all maker trades.
            If there is no maker base volume on the buy side, then this
            value is 0.
        buy_maker_base (float):Quantity for this day where the account
            was a maker on the buy side of the trade.
        buy_maker_notional (float): Notional value for this day where the
            account was a maker on the buy side of the trade.
        buy_maker_count (float):Number of trades for this day where the
            account was a maker on the buy side of the trade.
        sell_maker_base (float): Quantity for this day where the account
            was a maker on the sell side of the trade.
        sell_maker_notional (float): Notional value for this day where the
            account was a maker on the sell side of the trade.
        sell_maker_count (float): Number of trades for this day where the
            account was a maker on the sell side of the trade.
        buy_taker_base (float): Quantity for this day where the account was
            a taker on the buy side of the trade.
        buy_taker_notional (float): Notional value for this day where the
            account was a taker on the buy side of the trade.
        buy_taker_count (float): Number of trades for this day where the
            account was a taker on the buy side of the trade.
        sell_taker_base (float): Quantity for this day where the account
            was a taker on the sell side of the trade.
        sell_taker_notional (float): Notional value for this day where the
            account was a taker on the sell side of the trade.
